creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund and the Mary Griggs Burke Endowment Fund established by the Mary Livingston Griggs and Mary Griggs Burke Foundation; purchase from the Thomas Murray Collection
text: This mﾅ行en (felt rug) dates to the nineteenth century and is made of felted wool. Mﾅ行en are dyed bright colors, and this example features a background of bright red with small white shibori roundels and large white roundels augmented with yellow and green dye. Because felted wool is so thick, decorating this type of fabric requires a skilled and experience dyer. This textile was made in Mongolia and subsequently exported to Japan where it was dyed.
title: Red felt rug (mﾅ行en) decorated with roundels
